entry.title: Leopard
entry.content:
A wish List

Spotlight

Firstly spotlight. Now really like spotlight, the promise of a completely OS-level disk search tool sounded great, it worked pretty good too, if you were happy to wait for it to finish searching your entire harddrive for ‘a’, then ‘ap’, then ‘app’ etc. Hopefully Leopard will supercharge spotlight, then i might be able to ditch Quicksilver.

The Finder

Arrrr, ok, we all hate the finder, and have done for quite some time, we know this, Apple knows this. although Apple has yet to release details, we all know the finder is in for a make-over, but please Apple, whatever you do, don’t add bloody tabs to it. I really cannot think of a worst use of UI, than tabs for a file management tool. My reason, the most common operation the finder does is moving/copying files, which doesn’t lend itself to tabs. Instead, i would like to see improvements to the side-bar and context menus. But hey, who knows, we might get a 3D finder?

Safari

Safari gets the upgrade to Webkit v3, pretty much a given.

UI

As everyone else has commented, a more unified UI would be pretty nice, both in style and consistancy

entry.title: Styling the Flickr Badge
entry.summary: As I’m going around trying to smarten this place up, I ran into a problem with the Flickr Badge. First, It has a maximum of ten image thumbs. Second, even the small thumbnails are pretty big. Time to get out...
entry.content:
As I’m going around trying to smarten this place up, I ran into a problem with the Flickr Badge. First, It has a maximum of ten image thumbs. Second, even the small thumbnails are pretty big. Time to get out the coding equivilent of an axe.

First, the Limited number of images

When you do the wizard on Flickr to create a badge of your photos, it has a limited number of options to change the number of photos to display. Ok, this is easliy hacked by changing the code at the end, nut it max’s out at 10. Even if you type 30, it will only display 10. So, getting around this should be easy, simply paste the code more than once into your HTML. Nope! You’ll get the same ten photos twice, notsure if this is a bug or deliberate, but it’s not quite what we were looking for. Try making another badge that only gets its photos from one of your tags, or random, or set etc.

Making the Thumbs smaller

Next up, the default small thumbnail was too big to sit nicly into my design idea. To correct this, [CSS enters stage right] we’ll be using our friend CSS. Forcing a width and height onto .flickr_badge_image a img resizes the img. Obviously only resize an image smaller than the original, and try to keep the proportion correct. I’ve used 32×32 pixels as its about half the size of 75×75 pixels.

entry.title: &nbsp;
entry.summary: There was once a time when I could type this character combination without having to think too much about what order the ‘n’, ‘b’, ‘s’ and ‘p’ went. For those of you who don’t know this entity very well, it’s...
entry.content:
There was once a time when I could type this character combination without having to think too much about what order the ‘n’, ‘b’, ‘s’ and ‘p’ went. For those of you who don’t know this entity very well, it’s the non-breaking-space entity. It used to be the most overly used of all the entities, it was the web designers best friend. So why doesn’t anyone use them anymore?

The reason this entity gained fame and fortune has more to do with arcane voodoo, than good coding. It was used during the great table dynasty [1995—2002], when the only way to layout a two coloum grid was to have a two column table. EYou see, everything was done with tables, say you wanted a margin seperating these two columns, easy, just add another column! it really was that simple. But, this middle column wouldn’t have any text in it, it soul purpuse was to make a bit of space between the content column and the sidebar column. Which in some browsers could cause unexpected results, so any web desinger worth their namesake would simlpy add &nbsp; entity to the column.

Now thing have changed. The separation of structure and style has killed the need to the arcane zoodoo of table layout, and with it, the   entity was left in the gutter (litterally). The web has forgotton how useful this little entity can be.

What is this   thing anyway?

Its full name is non-breaking space, its entity reference is &nbsp;, and its entity code is &#160;. As the name suggests, when rendered by a browser, it is a space, just like any other space. But, and here’s the clever bit, this space will not break/wordwrap at the end of a line of text. Instead, the browser will find the nearest space before and break there. Why would you want to do this? It keeps words together, thats why.

Example

Say i’m writing some copy for a web site, Its not much, just one paragraph about 10 lines long. At the end of the first line is the company name, “Crazyman Company”. But the “Crazyman” and the “Company” are on different lines because they don’t both fit on the first line, so “Company” gets wrapped onto the line below. Simple, instead of typing “Crazyman Company”, use “Crazyman&nbsp;Company. Now the browser will wrap at the space before the “Crazyman” so the company name stays together, giving it more impact and making it easier to read.

OK, but why?

Beacuse it looks nicer, you’re supposed to be a web designer? go figure.
